Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Geoinformatics for Environmental and Energy Modeling and Prediction (GEEMaP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award to the University of Iowa supports an interdisciplinary graduate training program designed to train students to use advanced computational methods to address real-world problems in environmental science and energy production.

This novel Ph.D. training program uses team-based research projects, internships, and international research experiences to produce a new generation of quantitative and computational scientists who are prepared for interdisciplinary collaboration with engineers, social and natural scientists, government policy-makers, and industrial leaders in the global arena of environment and energy production. Geoinformatics--the science of measuring, storing, managing, analyzing and visualizing data related to phenomena occurring on or near the earth's surface--plays a key unifying role in the curriculum. Applications include prevention, control, and mitigation of floods; remediation of air, soil, and water contamination; and increasing wind and hydroelectric energy production--challenges that directly impact human health, safety, and quality of life. The project will broaden the participation of students from populations underrepresented in the science, technology, engineering and mathematical fields (women, U.S. ethnic minorities, and low-income and rural students) through coordination with established and successful recruitment programs at the University of Iowa, offering these students a unique program of innovative science, policy, and technology-based rotations. Student and faculty research results will contribute new computational tools and methods as well as scientific insights that will support the formulation of new environmental policy at the local, regional, national, and global scales.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Iowa was the home of the NSF Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) program entitled Geoinformatics for Environmental and Energy Modeling and Prediction (GEEMaP). Trainees were doctoral students in the departments of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Geographical and Sustainability Sciences, Statistics, and Biostatistics.

 The educational and training component of the grant offered collaborative research and professional development opportunities that complemented the graduate education that trainees received in their individual departments. Trainees from all departments met together weekly for a seminar, which focused on a different topic each semester. Topics included ethics in environmental research, grant writing, scientific writing, communication of science to the general public, and career opportunities for Ph.D.s in environmental science. Trainees also engaged in internships to obtain real-world experience. Former trainees are now working in academia, government, and industry.

Collaborative research achievements of this program addressed multiple areas of importance to environmental scientists, farmers, local governments, and citizens. Research results have appeared in journal articles and conference presentations in the areas of Geography, Statistics, and Engineering. Examples of research questions addressed by trainees were:

1. How do land characteristics and farming practices affect soil erosion, water quality, and climate change?  "Carbon sequestration" refers to the fact that trees and plants extract carbon dioxide (CO2) from the air through photosynthesis and store it in roots and, as plants decay, in soils. Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas, and increases in its atmospheric levels contribute to global climate change. Trainees investigated which agricultural practices may improve the ability of the soil to retain carbon and thus may help to offset the effects of fossil fuel use and other human activities that increase atmospheric CO2. Soil erosion is an important problem in agricultural areas. Erosion degrades farmland and carries nutrients and sediment into nearby waterways where they impact fish and other aquatic life. Trainees developed models to estimate how much of the run-off in rivers came from different types of surrounding land, such as forest and farm fields. They also investigated how characteristics of the land surface and soil, as well as farming practices, affect erosion.

2. Where is the next Flint, Michigan? Trainees combined data from government and volunteer sources to study the chemical characteristics of river and stream water that feeds public drinking water supplies in several Midwestern states. They identified locations in which surface water has corrosive properties that could cause leaching of lead from pipes.

3. How would frac sand mining affect the environment, economy, and quality of life in Winneshiek County in northeast Iowa? A special type of sand, which is used by the oil and gas industry in the hydraulic fracturing ("fracking") method of extracting petroleum from deep rock formations, occurs beneath the land surface in Winneshiek county. GEEMaP trainees and faculty participated in an interdisciplinary project of the Iowa Initiative for Sustainable Communities to assist the Board of Supervisors in Winneshiek County to decide whether to permit frac sand mining and processing in their county and, if so, how to regulate it. The role of GEEMaP trainees was to develop a model to predict where in Winneshiek County mining companies would be most likely to wish to site sand mines and processing plants. The information from this predictive model was passed to a team in Urban and Regional Planning, who assessed the potential impact on roads, water resources, outdoor recreation, and other aspects of county life. Preliminary results were presented to the county supervisors and residents in a video conference, and final results were presented to the local citizenry in a town meeting.

The broader impacts of the project include expanding participation of underrepresented groups, research addressing societal needs, and efforts to increase public scientific literacy and engagement. Most GEEMaP trainees were from one or more groups underrepresented in scientific and mathematical fields, including women, U.S. minorities, and first-generation college students. Trainees gave presentations to AP classes in Human Geography at a Cedar Rapids, Iowa, high school. One trainee actively participated in a low-impact development planning team for the City of Cedar Rapids to consider street design for stormwater management as part of 2017-2018 road construction plans. Another trainee worked with the city of Dubuque in developing a flood resilience survey. The trainees hosted a public workshop introducing ways in which ordinary citizens can participate in research in environmental science.
